“You mean aside from the fact that I risked my life to rescue her? Something neither you nor her ex-boyfriend could be bothered to do?” hearing Ashley give a faint chuckle, I continued, “I’ve done more for her in the last 10 months than you probably have in your entire life.

“How dare you...”

“No, ma’am, how dare you.” Getting angry, I said, “I love your daughter more than anything in the world. If you can’t get past your low opinion of me to see that she loves me too, then I feel sorry for you.”

Ashley had to cover her mouth to keep from laughing, as we heard her mom stammer over the radio. “This isn’t over, young man.”

The radio went silent for a few moments; enough time for Ashley to look at me and say, “You’re my hero, Jamie; you did what I was afraid to do for years. You stood up to my mother.”

“I survived the end of the world; dealing with my mother-in-law is a piece of cake.”

Suddenly Elena’s voice came over the speaker; “You guys mind explaining why I nearly got trampled in the hallway by a very irate woman?”

“Sorry about that, Elena.” Grabbing the microphone, Ashley said, “Jamie just told my mom off, and I guess she wasn’t happy about it.”

“Wish I could’ve been here to witness that.” Chuckling, Elena said, “I spoke with the teacher in charge of the kindergarten program; she’s more than willing to let Caleb participate in her class every few days.”

“Thanks for doing that, Elena.” Smiling, Ashley said, “We figured a trained teacher would be a better choice than us teaching him.”

“Roger that, Ashley.” Chuckling, Elena said, “Before I let you guys go, there was something I wanted to ask.”

Ashley and I looked at each other; wondering what was about to happen. Taking the microphone, I said, “Go ahead, Elena.”

“Jamie; I was wondering if, during our weekly contact, you’d like to play a game of chess?” pausing, Elena said, “I’m not nearly as good as Ashley, but I think I can still give you a challenge.”

“Sure, I don’t see why not.”

“Great, I’ll scrounge up a chess set; see you in a week.”
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Talking with Appalachia (Day 304)

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
It was a quiet day in the bunker; I was reading a book, Ashley was doing some laundry and Caleb was taking part in his first kindergarten class. We’d been assured by the teacher that today was just a formality; but she thought the other students would want to hear about Caleb’s life in the bunker.

So that’s what he’d been doing for the last 30 minutes; pretty much going over his entire life story from Samson to now. Ashley and I choked up a little when we overheard him say that he’s grateful that we took him in and that he loves us.

Eventually Caleb stopped talking about the bunker; I guess the teacher said the students had questions for him. But before he could answer any of them, he got up and walked out of the room. I was about to go after him when I saw him walking back with Ashley following closely behind him.

“What’s going on, babe?”

“I don’t know.” Looking at me, Ashley said, “Caleb just told me that there’s someone on the radio who wants to talk with me.”

As Ashley took a seat at the radio, I said, “Hmm, I wonder who it could be.”

“Hello, this is Ashley.” After a brief pause, she smiled and said, “David? Is it really you?”

David was Ashley’s younger half-brother; from what I gathered they had a close-knit relationship. I figured he was just calling to check-in; at least until I saw the frown on Ashley’s face. “W-What?” gasping, Ashley said, “When did this happen?”

Fearing the worst, I walked over to her and said, “Ash, what’s wrong?”

Looking at me, tears starting to form, Ashley said, “My folks just separated.”
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Caleb's First Day (Day 306)

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
I wasn’t entirely sure that I’d heard her correctly so, for clarification, I said, “I’m sorry, what?”

“My parents are separated; or at least as much as they can be inside a sealed bunker.” Running a hand through her hair, Ashley said, “Apparently things have been pretty bad for a while; until we made contact, they were pretty sure that I was dead. I guess they each blamed the other for leaving me behind.”

“I hate to say it; but they’re not wrong.” Pausing, I said, “Sure, you carry some of the blame for walking off; but they could’ve done more to stop you.”

Ashley gave me an evil look for a brief moment; until she composed herself. “Jamie, I love you; but it now isn’t the time to lecture me about what happened at school.”

“Sorry.” Sighing, I said, “How’s David doing with all this?”

“He says he’s fine; but I’m not sure I believe him.” Getting up, pacing around the room, Ashley said, “He’s only 14 years old; with Samson and now this, I’m not sure how much more he can handle.”

I wish I had a better idea of what to do in this situation; but I didn’t, so I simply decided to take Ashley’s hand in mine. Looking at her, I said, “I’ll understand if you don’t want to, at least not yet; but you might want to talk with your folks. Get their sides of the story rather than hearing it second hand from your brother.”

“I should do that; and I will.” Pacing again, Ashley said, “But not yet; if I talk to either of them right now, it won’t end well.”

**************************


After having a subdued, albeit tense, family lunch; Ashley decided to contact Appalachia to speak with her parents. As we waited for a response, I walked over and said, “Who are you going to talk to first?
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Ashley's Bad News

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Ashley paced around for a moment, before turning to me with a determined look on her face. “I’m probably going to regret this; I’m almost positive that I will, but I think I’ll talk to my Mom first.” Sighing, Ashley said, “Knowing how stubborn she is, I have a feeling that she’s the main cause of all this.”

Heading over to the radio, I said, “Okay then; you go figure out what you’re going to say, while I get Appalachia on the radio.”

It took only a few minutes for Appalachia to respond; and only a few more after that for Mrs. Saunders to come over the radio.
“Hello?”

The microphone had a speakerphone feature, so I enabled that for Ashley to use. Standing behind me, pacing around again,
Ashley said, “I heard about you and Dad; you mind telling me what happened?”

“I would think it’s obvious, Ashley; you, and your poor choice in husbands, were the cause.” Sighing, Mrs. Saunders said, “Your father refused to accept that that Jamie boy wasn’t good enough for you. You deserve to be with someone who can provide for you.”

I struggled to contain my anger; after all, I could only take so much. Meanwhile, Ashley stepped closer and said, “Jamie’s doing a fine job of providing for me, Mother; the bunker’s fine and we’ve got enough supplies to last for 3 years.” Sighing, Ashley said,
“We both know that Eric wouldn’t have been able to do half of what Jamie’s done.”

“I suppose my only consolation is that you haven't gotten in trouble yet.”

It took me a moment to realize what exactly Mrs. Saunders meant by that remark. I’d walked over to the kitchen to clean up a mess Caleb left, while Ashley continued her conversation. “For your information, Mother, we came pretty close a few months back.” Sighing, Ashley said, “There are times that I find myself wishing that it hadn’t been a false alarm; because I would certainly be a much better mother than you.”

“How dare you, you ungrateful child; after everything I’ve done for you.” Practically screaming, Mrs. Saunders said, “You’d be nothing if it weren’t for me.”

As I stood in the kitchen, I watched Ashley start fuming; to the point where I imagined smoke coming from her ears. “You know, Mother; this whole time I thought I was missing out on not being with you in that bunker.” Grabbing the microphone, Ashley said,

“But the more I hear you talk; the happier I am that I won’t see you for another 3 years. I can only hope that’s long enough to undo all the damage you’ve done.”

“Ashley Saunders, if you...”

With a smug grin, Ashley reached over and flipped the power switch for the radio. Looking at me, she said, “That felt good.”

Walking over to her, holding a glass in my hands, I said, “How come you never told me about that thing with the pregnancy?”

“I wasn’t sure how you’d react; if you’d feel the same way that I did.” Looking at me, Ashley said, “I do want to have your baby, Jamie.”

I knew where this was leading; because it’s happened several times over the last several months. Ashley was going to try and convince me to get her pregnant, and I’d have to talk her out of it. I hated having to do that; because I wanted nothing more than to have a baby with her. But the situation we found ourselves in wasn’t conducive to raising a newborn. “Ash, how many times have we talked about this? We’re still learning how to be parents to Caleb; do you want to throw a baby into the mix?”

“I suppose you’re right.” Taking a deep breath, Ashley said, “But there will be a time, Jamie Lincoln, where I’ll be pregnant with your child.”
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Mom

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
After the tense conversation with her Mom, Ashley wasn’t exactly looking forward to talking with her Dad. But I managed to talk her into it; and, judging from what I could hear, she had a pleasant conversation with them.

***************************


That was yesterday; today I decided that the three of us would have a lazy day. So what did we do? We stayed in our pajamas all day and watched movies. Caleb knew about Ashley’s talk with her mom (he refused to think of her as his grandmother, unlike my mom). With that in mind, I wasn’t surprised to see that he clung to her like glue.

I’ll admit that I was a tad jealous; Caleb was spending more time with my wife than I was. But in the end, I knew everything was alright.

After putting Caleb down for his nap, Ashley joined me in the kitchen. Looking at her, I said, “What’s on your mind, babe?”

“Promise me that we won’t end up like my parents.” Looking at me, forlorn, Ashley said, “Promise me that if times get tough, we’ll stick together and work things out.”

“I promise, Ash; we won’t end up like your parents.” With a weak chuckle, I said, “I suppose it helps that we love each other, unlike them.”

Ashley glared at me for a moment; as if I’d said something wrong. Her glare turned to a frown as she said, “They did love each other at one point; before my mom got obsessed with her social status.” Sighing, Ashley said, “When Caleb’s old enough to date, I hope against hope that I don’t do to his girlfriend what my mom’s done to you.”

“Ash, babe, you’re a much better person than your mother.” Holding her close, with a smile, I said, “Besides we don’t have to worry about that for a long time; because Caleb isn’t going to be dating until he’s our age.”
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Ashley's Depressed (Day 307)

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
The next couple of weeks weren’t good for Ashley; I was beginning to think the stress from our situation was getting to her, and the news of her parent’s separation didn’t help matters. She’d grown withdrawn; barely saying anything to me or Caleb the last few days.

Caleb, for his part, didn’t fully understand what was going on; but he knew his mother wasn’t happy. He tried to cheer her up but it didn’t work. Things came to a head this morning when I woke up to find that Ashley wasn’t in bed. I sat up in bed as I heard an alarm blaring in the distance; one I quickly recognized as the air quality alarm.

I scrambled out of bed and made my way to the maintenance room; my concern about Ashley’s whereabouts superseded for the moment. I was justifiably confused when a look at the monitoring system showed that all the filters were working at or above 90%. Walking through the bunker, I soon realized the source of the problem – the surface hatch was open, and there was a suit missing.

Caleb came walking out of his room at the point. Rubbing his eyes, he said, “Daddy? What’s going on?”

“Go back to your room, little man.” Clamoring into the other suit, I said, “I’ll be right back.”

Within minutes I was up on the surface; I made my way around the outside of the house but found no sign of footprints. I’d been calling out for Ashley for the last five minutes but got no response. I was about to go back and use the drone when I saw a flash of light coming from one of the upstairs windows.

Rushing back into the house, I went upstairs to find Ashley in what had been her parents’ bedroom; lying on the bed as she looked at a photo album. Walking up to her, I said, “Ash, what the hell are you doing? You’re not supposed to come to the surface without telling me.”

No emotion in her voice, Ashley said, “I wanted to find proof that my parents did truly love each other.” Gesturing to the photo album, Ashley said, “They’re smiling in every one of those photos; they were happy and in love. What could have possibly changed all that?”

“People fall out of love, Ash, it happens all the time.” Sitting next to Ashley, I said, “Just look at you and Brian; you guys were happy together, or at least you appeared that way. It’s not your fault that he cheated on you; just like it’s not you’re not to blame for your parents separating.”

Ashley was silent for a moment; until she looked at me and said, “What if that happens to us? What if we reach a point where we no longer love each other?”

“That’s not going to happen, Ash.” Looking at her, I said, “I can’t believe you’d even think that.”

“Can you blame me though? We both hid our true feelings from each other for years; then we get married after dating for barely 3 months.”

I slowly realized what she was getting at. Taking her hand, I said, “Are you concerned that we moved too quickly?”

Ashley went silent again, thinking about her answer. After a moment, she looked at me and said, “Yes.”
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Ashley's Downward Spiral (Day 321)

1112.content:
Knowing we would not be able to run far, I pulled Ashley into the parking lot of the bus depot and ducked down among the seemingly countless vehicles. "We need an old four by four if we are going to get anywhere." Whispering, I said.

"Wait a minute..." Startled, Ashley whispered back. "Are you seriously suggesting we steal a car?!"

"We have to assume we are good as dead if they catch us." Darkly, I countered. "Anyway, once Samson hits, all of these cars are going to be destroyed."

Ashley sighed. "Okay, point taken but who taught you how to steal a car?"

I smiled. "Auto shop class, my senior year."

I pulled Ashley along as I searched for the car we needed and soon came across an old model four by four truck with the driver's door left open. without a sound, I urged Ashley in who crawled to the passenger seat while I jumped in and reached under the console. After feeling around for a moment, I pulled out a small number of wires. Details aside, I got the truck started and pulled the door closed.

"Um... Jamie..." Wincing, Ashley said.

I turned and found a number of rioters running for the truck. "Hang on!"

I hit the accelerator, sending the truck screaming forward and drove through the lot, straight for the exit. Two rioters got into vehicles and gave chase. "they're after us for stealing a truck!" Frightened, Ashley yelled.

"They're after us because they're all mad and need someone to blame." Serious, I countered. "We're just teenagers so we're easy targets."

Ashley gulped at that, it was not a pleasant thought. The two who had jumped into cars to gave chase used their cars to block the exit but I was taught how to drive on the back roads. "Jamie, they're blocking our way out!" Screaming, Ashley warned.

I gave a chuckle. "Buckle up..."

Ashley's eyes went wide before buckling herself up and grabbed onto her seat for dear life. I turned the wheel and charged the car off the lot into the grass towards an old dirt road in a nearby forest. "They're nuts if they give chase." glancing at the rear view I thought. "Only a four by four can handle these roads." To my surprise, the two cars did give chase onto the road. "Yup... they're nuts."

"You are insane!" Angry, Ashley yelled. "You are insane!"

"They're insane for following." Darkly, I replied. "This road was not made with luxury cruisers in mind."

It did not take long for my words to ring true as I took a sharp turn on the dirt road. the first car was not able to turn fast enough and ended up sliding sideways right into a tree at high speed. The second ca managed to make the turn only the diver was not ready for a steep hill shortly after. While the four by four was able to climb the hill, the car fell short and rolled back before flipping three times to the bottom.

"I guess you do know what you are doing..." Wincing, Ashley muttered.

"We got away from them, that's all that matters." Softly, I said. "What we need to do now is find some form of shelter."

"Why can't we follow the buses?" Shrugging, Ashley asked.

"The route was top secret as was the location of the bunkers." Serious, I replied. "Even if we knew where their route and where they were going, the fragments are hitting sooner than predicted."

"Which means Samson may hit sooner than predicted." Pale, Ashley said. "Why an old four by four though?"

"The newer models have safeguards to protect from the old tricks." Serious, I replied. "Now focus, do you know of any place close hand?"

Ashley sighed, tears forming. "I know a place..." Whispering, she said.

I followed Ashley's instructions and we soon arrived at...
1112.title: Wild Ride.

All the comforts of a modern mansion.
11123.content:
We soon arrived at a huge ten foot steel door built into the sheer face of a mountain. Ashley jumped out of the truck and hurried to it, fumbling through her purse. She soon produced a key card and inserted it into a small crevice near the door. A low beep was heard and a panel opened revealing a keypad. She punched in a code, opening a another panel that looked like a scanner. "Put your left hand onto the screen." Serious, she ordered. "I'm logging you in."

Curious, I placed my hand onto the sensor and I felt the sensor vibrate before a beep was heard. Ashley then pushed me aside to place her hand onto the screen. Again, a beep was heard and she removed her key card. Both panels closed and a deep hollow clang was heard before the heavy steel door slowly lifted. "Walk casually, don't run." Darkly, Ashley warned. "You will understand once you pass the main hall."

I nodded and followed Ashley inside where she again inserted her key card and punched in a code. The heavy door slowly fell, sealing the entrance with a heavy clang and a hiss before she motioned me to follow. The entry hall was cared out of solid rock and seemed to go on forever. Upon reaching the end, I was greeted by an awe inspiring sight. We were at the edge of an underground cavern abyss. "Welcome to Demon's Mouth cavern." Calmly, Ashley said. "My father discovered it ten years ago and built a fortress to survive almost literally anything."

I looked out over the abyss and found several stone bridges leading to a stone fortress on the other side deep inside the mountain. "It looks familiar..." Curious, I said.

Ashley sighed. "It was inspired by a novel called The Buried kingdom."

I gasped. "My father wrote that!"

Ashley nodded. "Why do you think he and your dad got along so well." Frowning, she said. "He helped dad build it."

I frowned back. "I don't remember him coming home with a pay check..."

"I honestly don't know what the deal was." Annoyed, Ashley spat. "My father kept business and home strictly separate."

I sighed. "My dad was like that too..."

"Look, we don't exactly like each other... in fact we can't stand each other." Her face softening, Ashley said. "However, like it or not, we need each other right now."

Of course, I knew Ashley was right and I offered my hand. "A truce then...?"

Ashley took my hand and shook it. "Truce..." She then turned to the bridges. "I hope you know your father's novel better than me. Dad warned me that there was only one way to cross any one of the bridges or you will fall to your death."

I nodded. "The only was to cross is to walk slowly and lightly." Serious, I said. "In the story, there are trap doors that will barely hold the weight of a grown man. If you run, the trap door opens but if you walk, it holds your weight."

Ashley gulped and nodded. Together, we carefully walked across the bridge without incident to the fortress itself. It looked almost exactly like a castle of old only, if it followed my father's story, the inside was even more awe inspiring. "Do you have the key to the door?"

Ashley nodded and inserted the same key card into a slot near the door. a panel opened revealing another key pad and scanner. she hit a code and motioned me to put my hand onto the scanner. She then did the same and the massive door opened. It looked much like a door to a safe with multiple heavy rods holding the door closed. We both walked through after Ashley retrieved her card. "This is the furthest I have come into the fortress." Honestly, Ashley said.

I looked beyond the door and smiled. "Well, your father didn't exactly follow my dad's book on the internal design but still... not bad." Softly, I said.

Ashley looked passed me and gasped as she found...
11123.title: Fantasy to reality.

111232.content:
Ashley looked passed me and gasped as she found all the comforts of a modern mansion only the decor was modern medieval. Ashley and I were standing in a grand entry way with two sets of elegant stairs on either side of the far end that led to the upper floors. Between them was a hall to the rest of the first floor. The grand entry included two large fire places each with a generous supply of wood that reached to the high ceiling in a specially constructed chute.

"It's beautiful..." Whispering, Ashley said.

I sighed. "We can admire it later." To her frown, I said. "We need to make certain this place is secure before Samson hits... it will be too late after impact."

Although annoyed, Ashley nodded. "You're right... what do we do first?"

"We need to find the control room." Serious, I said. "I would imagine everything we need to activate, open or close would be operated from a central point."

"Only where would it be?" Wincing, Ashley asked.

"Personally, I would put it in the center most room." Thoughtful, I replied. "I suggest we work our way to the center of the castle and find it."

Ashley looked about before walking to a picture hanging on the wall. "The control center is twenty rooms in down the main hall." Studying the picture, she said. "It's the last door before the center stairwells." She turned to me. "Dad always framed the blueprints after each major job completed... his idea of a trophy."

I nodded then studied the blueprints myself. "The food stores are in the castle cellar and the armory is right next to the control center." Softly, I said. "We better take stock of what we have after we lock down."

Ashley nodded and we ran down the hall towards the control center...
111232.title: All the comforts of a modern mansion.

1112321.content:
After taking a picture of the blueprint with my iPhone, Ashley and I made our way to the control room where, to my inner delight, had the same configuration dad and I had worked on in blueprints for the novel. "I know these controls." Almost whispering, I said. "We will need two keys..."

Ashley looked around and spotted two strange keys in a display case on the wall. "There!" Running to them, she said. She opened the case and tossed one key to me. "What do we do next?"

"We have to turn them at the exact time to lock down the castle." Serious, I said. "It is designed to prevent one person from locking everyone else out."

"Makes sense." Wincing, Ashley said. "So... we lock everything down now?"

Her question was answered by an alarm suddenly sounding. I turned to a screen and swore under my breath. "Samson has hit early!" Panicked, I announced. "We need to lock down now or we won't make it through the impact!"

Ashley gulped then nodded. We inserted our key and on the count of three, we turned our key at the same time. More alarms sounded and we watched nervously as the monitors showed one heavy door after another slowly closing downwards with a loud clang and hiss. Just as the last door sealed, the entire castle was rocked with the shock waves from the meteor impact. Ashley and I both screamed as we were thrown off our feet. Sparks flew from the controls, lights above us burst, the monitors went dark and the power went out....

Moments later, a low hum was heard and the lights that had not burst flickered back on with the monitors soon following. "Are- Are you okay...?" Weakly, I asked.

"I'm still alive..." Weakly, Ashley replied. "You were right about Samson hitting early. Were we able to seal the base in time?"

"I'm not sure..." Wincing, I replied. I struggled to my feet then helped Ashley to hers. "We will need to check the cameras, if they still work."

I turned to the controls and activated the remote cameras. To my relief, all of the heavy gates were sealed and holding. I then switched to the external cameras and gulped. Everything, literally everything was on fire through the heavy haze... even the city in the far distance. "Mom... dad... Emma..." Whispering, I cried.

Ashley touched my shoulder. "I'm fearful for my family too." Whispering, she said.

I sighed then switched back to the internal cameras. "We- We should take stalk on- on what we have on supply." Tearfully, I stammered. "There's nothing else to do right now, anyway..."

I began to walk out of the control room. As I reached the door...
1112321.title: Locking down the castle.

11123212.content:
"We're both hurting, Jamie!" Pulling me back, Ashley said. "We should deal with that before anything else!"

I turned to Ashley with anger and tears in my eyes. "Tell me... what will crying all day do to help us?!" Tears falling, I demanded. "The last time I saw my sister, I told her crying isn't going to help anyone!" I vainly rubbed my tears, trying to make them stop. "What kind of big brother would I be if I bawl over my own guilt and sadness?!"

I did not wait for Ashley to respond, I ran from her, crying to myself. I knew Ashley was hurting too but my guilt over what I had said the Emma before the fragment hit was still weighing heavily upon my conscience. I found the food storage and found what looked like enough stowed away to feed an army for a year. If my initial estimate was correct, it would last two people several years. I walked further in and found a door to a refrigerated section but I did not open it. I instead slumped to the floor next to it and began to cry.

"I'm sorry, Emma....!" Wailing, I said. "I'm so... so sorry...!"

I do not know how long I had sat there, weeping but I jumped upon feeling someone wrap their arms around me. At first, I struggled but I stopped as Ashley's voice reached me. "Let it out..." Crying, she said. "We won't survive together if we don't..."

Slowly, hesitantly, I returned Ashley's embrace and we cried on each other's shoulders for what seemed like forever....
11123212.title: Two souls in pain.

111232122.content:
1 P.S. Day One... Post Samson.

After what seemed to be forever, we managed to compose ourselves and continue with the plan to make a count of what we had at our disposal. The food storage, dry, chilled and frozen was enough to sustain a small army for three years. The weapons stockpile was comparable to a fully stocked military base. This included three short range planes, two helicopters, eight jeeps, countless robot drones and enough ammunition to hold off a small army almost indefinitely. There was enough purified water to sustain a small army for three years, which would sustain two for significantly longer...

"We will be safe here... for a while." Sighing, I said. "Only we can't stay here forever."

"What do you mean?" Worried, Ashley asked.

"You know as much as I do that we will eventually need to know who or what survived the impact out there." Serious, I said. "The last report stated that the meteor was at least eighty one kilometers in diameter... the same size as the one that reportedly killed off the dinosaurs over sixty five million years ago."

Ashley gulped. "Do you really think there might be survivors out there?"

"There has to be." Tearing up, I said. "We can't just assume we are the only two to survive... the new 'Adam' and 'Eve'."

Ashley wrinkled her nose. "Ew..." She sighed. "Since you put it that way... there better be survivors out there."

She giggled with me slowly chuckling a moment after. "We had some hope..."
111232122.title: Counting inventory.

1112321222.content:
After some deliberation, we decided to send out two remote controlled drones to scout the immediate area. It was a logical choice if nothing else to see if there were any major damages to the outside of the stronghold.. Ashley and I each piloted one of the drones and looked over the outside of the castle. Fortunately, there were no major damages and the bridges were still intact. Moving the drones to the outside through an access tunnel, we flew the drones to the outside to find that the temperatures were at 110 Fahrenheit and rising with the heat radiation from Samson. Fortunately, the drones were made to survive such conditions. The cliff side was scorched by the blast wave from Samson but it was still intact.

"Your dad built the castle well." Softly, I said.

"Your father designed it." softly, Ashley countered.

I nodded and we each piloted our drones in a different direction. Ashley flew her drone towards the school where we were to be picked up to be taken to the bunkers. I flew mine towards the city, hoping to find some signs that someone had survived. For what seemed like an eternity, it did not seem that we would find anything with the short range drones we had sent out. Only we held out hope...
1112321222.title: Sending out drones.

11123212223.content:
We were close to calling the drones back after nearly an hour of finding nothing when Ashley cried out, "I think I found something."

"What is it?" Turning to her monitor, I asked.

"It's a thin flume of smoke not to far from where my drone is." Serious, Ashley replied. "Maybe a campfire..."

"Maybe." Nodding, I agreed. "I would not bring the probe too close, it might attract more people than we can accommodate."

Ashley sighed but reluctantly agreed. She pushed the probe forward just above the charred trees that remained standing to the line of smoke. There we found a large campfire with a total of four survivors... a father, mother, son and daughter. They were all badly injured with the small boy injured the most. "Those poor people..." Tearing up, Ashley said. "Can't we..."

I paused, hearing a beep from my probe and turned to my monitor to find a bunker that had survived. "I found a bunker." Softly, I said. "Maybe we can lure them there..."

"And if they have no room..." Wearily, Ashley asked.

I sighed. "Then we will lead them here."

"We know we have room here for a small army for three years." Serious, Ashley said. "A family of four is not going to mess things up too badly."

"Either way it's a risk." Darkly, I countered. "I don't like the idea of leaving anyone out there in that nightmare but we have to be careful."

"What if we bring them to the cave, just the cave..." After a thought, Ashley argued. "At least there they will find shelter and give us time to determine if they are safe to allow to enter the castle."

"Still a risk." Sighing, I said. "But... we can't guarantee what they will find at the bunker of if it is even usable."

"Well, we better decide now because they've spotted the drone." Serious, Ashley said.

I looked at the monitor and swallowed down a tear seeing the little girl hold up a sign that read 'HELP'...

Making up her mind, Ashley took up a microphone that was remotely linked to a speaker on the drone. "Are you able to travel?" The family wearily nodded.

I then picked up the microphone. "There is a bunker about a quarter mile to the west of your position." Calmly, I said. "We are half a mile to the south of your position. It is your choice... walk to the west and take your chances or trust us and follow the drone to the south."

The four turned to each other with pained faces. It was not an easy decision for anyone in their situation and I hated to do that but I also did not want to leave them with no choice at all. Finally, the mother and father took up one end of a stretched the boy was lying on and began walking with the little girl following to...
11123212223.title: continue.

12.content:
Even though Samson wasn’t due to strike for another three days, fragments had been striking the planet for the last week. There were so much dust and smoke in the air that the sky looked like a perpetual sunset. I probably would’ve thought it pretty had it not been for what was coming.

My name is Ashley Saunders, I’m a 17-year-old girl from West Virginia and I’m praying the I survive the coming apocalypse. My boyfriend Eric and I were on a bus heading to the Appalachian Bunker; a large underground complex, underneath the Appalachian Mountains, designed to hold 3000 for three years. Admittance to the bunker was determined by a lottery; both Eric’s family and mine had been evacuated in an earlier group.

Turning away from a dozing Eric, I looked out the window to see another fragment enter the atmosphere in the distance. I watched it until it went below the tree line, followed seconds later by the tremors caused by its impact. I can’t believe the world is coming to an end.

I was so deep in thought that I failed to notice the large tree that had fallen in the road up ahead; thankfully the driver of the bus saw it just in time. Unfortunately, the bus couldn’t stop in time; everyone was rather violently bounced around as the bus went up and over the downed tree.

Eric woke up at that moment and, oblivious to the situation, turned to look at me. “Are we there?”

I stared back out the window for a moment before turning to Eric in disdain. “No Eric, we’re not there yet.”
As the bus driver and the Evac leader got out to check the damage, Eric closed his eyes and said, “Wake me when we get there, alright babe?”

I rested my head against the seat back as I reconsidered some of my life decisions. I got straight A’s in school; why am I dating a guy who flunked every class but lunch? Then I remembered why we were together; I was Cheer captain and he was the school’s star quarterback.

Looking around the bus, I spotted a familiar face a few rows behind me. Jamie Lincoln wasn’t in my social circle; but he was still a sweet guy, kind of dorky but still sweet. I’d never admit to it publicly but I’d had a crush on him since the 8th grade.

I casually waved at him once I saw him looking at me; he waved back but I could tell he was confused. I couldn’t really blame him; after all, I spent the last 2 years making his life difficult.

Somewhere in the distance, I could hear an approaching fragment burning its way through the atmosphere. I found myself hoping that we’d be moving again soon, but that hope was dashed when the driver came back on the bus a few minutes later. “I’m sorry folks, but hitting that tree snapped the front axle clean in half.” With a heavy sigh, he said, “We’ve called for another bus from Appalachia, but there’s room for 6 if anyone doesn’t feel like waiting.”

Everyone was then unloaded from the bus and left to spread out along the side of the road. With my backpack in hand, I was heading towards a nearby rock when Eric grabbed my arm. “Come on babe, there’s still three more spots on the bus.”

“You go ahead, I’ll wait for the next one.”

Looking at me, incredulous, Eric said, “What, are you serious?”

“With everything that’s been going on, I think I just need some time to myself.” Looking at him, feeling rather despondent, I said,
“I’ll catch up to you at the bunker, alright?”

I wasn’t surprised in the least when Eric didn’t even try to convince me otherwise. “Okay then, I’ll see you around.”
I watched as Eric turned and headed back towards the buses; making a bee-line for an attractive girl standing outside the bus. I sat down on the rock and watched as they boarded the bus, mere moments before it drove off.

I hadn’t been lying when I told Eric I wanted time to myself; I was taking the opportunity to rethink my entire relationship with him.
There were some good times in our one-year-long relationship; but honestly, were they enough to justify staying with him?

I was so deep in thought that I hadn’t realized someone was next to me; until I felt a hand on my shoulder and heard someone say, “Are you okay?”

Turning to my right, I saw _______.
12.title: Second Guessing Life Choices

121.content:
I let out an audible sigh of relief when I realized it was Jamie; although my relief was quickly replaced with concern, once I noticed the pained expression on Jamie’s face. Looking at him, concerned, I said, “Are you alright? You look like you’re in pain.”

“During the chaos out there I think I twisted my ankle.” Wincing, Jamie said, “I’m not sure how much further I can go before the pain becomes too much.”

Hearing footsteps in the distance, I realized it wasn’t going to be long before someone found us. I didn’t want to wait to see if they were good or not. Turning back to Jamie, I said, “The nurses’ office is right down the hall; if we can get there, I’ll see about fixing your ankle.”

Any trepidation that Jamie might’ve had vanished as the sound of approaching footsteps got louder. Looking at me, he said, “I suppose I’ll be better off with you.”

With my arm wrapped under Jamie’s shoulder for support, the two of us slowly made our way down the hall. It took us a few minutes to get there, but we finally made it. Still supporting Jamie with one arm, I used my other arm to try and open the door.

“Damn, it’s locked.” Banging on the door, I said, “Hello is anyone in there?”

After no answer, I started to panic; it wouldn’t be long before Jamie and I were found. Jamie was in no condition to fight; and, given the current situation, I didn’t want to think about what would happen to me. I started knocking on the door again, “Please let us in; I’m begging you.”

Another few seconds went by before I heard the lock disengage, and the door opened a crack to reveal ____.
121.title: A Friendly Face?

1211.content:
The door opened just enough for me to see a man, probably in his early 30s, standing there. Looking at the two of us, he said,
“What do you want?”

“He’s injured; I just want to get some things to help him.” Getting nervous, I said, “Please let us in, I’m begging you.”

I began to suspect the man wasn’t alone in the office, because I watched him lean behind the door and whisper to someone. I couldn’t understand what was being said, but soon the man turned back to me and said, “Okay, you can come in; but don’t take too long.”

I helped Jamie into the room; only then did I notice a woman sitting nearby holding a scared little boy in her arms. They seemed to shaken up about something but I figured it was the pending disaster. After putting Jamie on one of the beds, I turned back to the man and said, “Thank you for letting us in; I was a little worried there for a second.”

“Don’t make me regret letting you in; I won’t let any harm come to my family.” Gesturing to Jamie, the man said, “Once you’ve tended to his injuries, you’re out of here.”

I wasn’t exactly thrilled about the idea of heading back out there, but I didn’t want to overstay my welcome. Giving the man a brief nod, I went to check on Jamie. While I slowly rolled up his pants leg, he looked at me and said, “I don’t mean to sound unappreciative; but why are you helping me?”

“Despite what you probably think of me, I’m not a bad person.” Looking up at Jamie, I said, “Just because I made your life difficult in school doesn’t mean I’d let you die.”

“Difficult?” scoffing, Jamie said, “You did more than make my life difficult; you were a downright jerk to me all through High School.”

“Look, we can waste time discussing every terrible thing I did to you in school, or you can let me help you.” Getting annoyed, I said, “It’s your choice, Jamie.”

Considering the situation we were in, I grew visibly annoyed when Jamie paused to think it over. After a moment, he said, “Okay fine, I guess you’re better than nothing.”

Once that was settled I got up and walked over to the supply cabinet. I was digging through the supplies for some bandages when I felt someone step up behind me. Thinking it was the man keeping an eye on me, I turned around; only to see the woman staring at me. “Turn around; make it look like you’re still searching.”

I was confused but decided to comply. As I went back to searching, I said, “Is something wrong, ma’am?”

“My son and I are in danger; can you help us?”

“We’re all in danger, ma’am; that asteroid is going to strike in three days.” Glancing back at the man, who was standing by the door, I said, “Besides I think your husband can take care of the situation.”

“That man’s not my husband.” Looking at me, she said, “He’s holding my son and me hostage.”
1211.title: A Frightened Man

12111.content:
I stared at the woman for a moment, unsure if I’d heard her correctly. Careful not to let anyone else hear me, I leaned closer and said, “I beg your pardon?”

“That man is not my husband; he grabbed my son and me during the chaos.” In a hushed tone, the woman said, “He said he wanted to use us as bargaining chips; so he could get into the bunker.”

I quickly turned to look at the man, still standing by the door; it was only then that I caught a faint glimpse of a gun sticking out of his pants. “What are we going to do?” turning back to the woman, I said, “Jamie can’t do anything, and the two of us are no match for him.”

“I wouldn’t count me out so quickly.” Rolling up her shirt sleeve, revealing a slightly faded Marine Corp tattoo, the woman said, “I served in the Marines for 6 years.”

“Okay, so you might be able to take him in a fight.” Sighing, I said, “But what about myself, Jamie and your son?”

“For now I think our best bet is to play along; then when the time comes, we make our escape.”

That sounded like a pretty good idea; then again, it’s not like we had many options. I was about to respond when suddenly the man came up behind us and said, “What are you ladies talking about?”

I was amazed by how quickly the woman could change gears; as she turned to the man and said, “I was just helping her find what she needed, honey.” Handing me some compression bandages, she said, “I think this will help your friend.”

If the man was on to us, he didn’t say anything. I simply nodded and took what I’d found back to Jamie. Once I was sure the man couldn’t hear me, I turned to him and said, “We’ve got a serious problem, Jamie.”
12111.title: Continue

121111.content:
“You mean besides the giant rock hurtling towards the planet?”

“Yeah; besides that.” As I went to work wrapping Jamie’s ankle, I said, “That man isn’t who he seems to be; he’s holding that woman and her son hostage.”

Looking past me, at the man, Jamie said, “Are you sure?”

“As sure as I can be; I mean, I’m just going by what that woman told me.”

Wincing in pain, Jamie said, “What exactly did she tell you?”

“That he grabbed her and her son during the chaos outside.” Pausing, I said, “Apparently he thinks he can use them to get a spot in the bunker.”

“I don’t think that will work out for him; the guards at the bunker are more likely to shoot everyone before they even get near the door.”

A noise out in the hall made everyone jump; as the man opened the door just enough to look outside. The woman, her son in tow, took the opportunity to make her way over to us. “Judging from the look on your friend’s face, I suspect you told him?”

“Yeah, she told me.” Taking a breath, Jamie said, “Forgive me, but why should we trust you?”

“I doubt any answer I give will be good enough.” Sighing, she said, “Just know that I’d never do anything that puts my son in harm’s way.”

Jamie relaxed a little after that, but I could tell he still had misgivings. I couldn’t blame him; after all, I had them as well. “I’m guessing you have some sort of plan?”

“I do, but I’m afraid your friend here won’t like it.”

“She and I aren’t friends; we’re not even in the same social group.” Sighing, Jamie said, “What’s your plan?”

“You’re going to go use the bathroom, but you’ll need his help to do so.” Pausing, the woman said, “Before you enter the bathroom, I’ll come up from behind; knocking him out and taking his gun.”

I can't say that I liked the idea of Jamie being in harm's way; but it made sense for him to be involved. After all, the man would probably realize something was odd if I or the woman asked him for bathroom help. It seemed that Jamie had the same concerns, as he looked at the woman and said, "I don't like the idea of being the bait here; but I guess we don't have much choice.”
121111.title: Making a Plan

1211111.content:
While everyone got ready, the woman brought her son over to me. “Can I trust you to keep my son safe; regardless of what might happen?”

“Yeah, I can do that.” Looking at Jamie, who was sitting nearby, I said, “Can you promise to keep Jamie safe?”

“I will try my best.”

The son, who couldn’t have been more than 7 years old, had no idea what was going on. He just clung tightly to me as we sat in the corner. I watched as Jamie waved the man over to him; saying, “Do you mind helping me use the bathroom?” pausing, Jamie said, “I don’t feel right asking one of the girls to help me.”

“Sure, I don’t see why not.” Helping Jamie to his feet, the man said, “I had an injury like that a few years ago; I couldn’t put any weight on it for almost a week.”

As the man helped Jamie towards the bathroom, I found myself feeling a little sorry for him. Sure he’d taken a woman and her son hostage; but he was only trying to survive. The woman, waiting until they got closer to the bathroom before she pounced, slowly came up behind them.

To his credit, Jamie was doing what he could to string the guy along; asking him about what he did before the world went to hell and other questions of that nature. “I was a history teacher at a community college a few towns over.” pausing to take a breath, oblivious to what was about to happen, the man said, “I didn’t get picked for the bunker, but I thought I could...”

Before the man could finish his sentence, the woman smacked him across the back of the head with a garbage can. While Jamie fell off to the side, out of the way, the woman removed the gun from the man’s pants and shoved him into the bathroom.

I quickly ran over to check on Jamie. “How are you feeling, Jamie?”

“I’ve been better.” Grunting in pain, Jamie said, “I think that guy was right; I won’t be able to put any weight on this for a while.”

Speaking of the man, we suddenly heard pounding coming from the other side of the door. Appearing in the window, he said,
“You a**holes better let me out; or so help me.”

“What are you going to do?” With a chuckle, the woman placed the gun against the glass and said, “I’ve got your gun, a**hole. Next time you want to take someone hostage; why don’t you make sure they’re not a former Marine.”

The son came running over to his mom at that point. As he hugged her, I said, “We should make a run for it while we still can; I don’t think that door will hold forever.”

As if to prove my point, the glass started to crack under the man’s repeated punches. “I think I saw some transportation behind the building.” Spotting a pair of crutches nearby, the woman looked at Jamie and said, “Do you think you can keep up; or do we need a wheelchair?”

“I’ll be fine, don’t worry about me.” Hobbling over to the crutches, Jamie said, “Let’s just get out of here.”
1211111.title: Putting the Plan Into Action

13.content:
Primary Characters:
• Jamie Lincoln – 17-year-old boy; average teenager, not very popular in school.
• Ashley Saunders – a 17-year-old girl; popular girl, realizes early on that popularity isn’t worth much in the new world.

Secondary Characters:
• Mr. & Mrs. Lincoln – Jamie’s parents
• Emma Lincoln – Jamie’s younger (15-year-old) sister
• Mr. & Mrs. Saunders - Ashley's mom and step-father.

Thread Specific:
• Caleb Anderson - 4 years old; survived on the surface with his parents for a month. Moves into the bunker; and is informally adopted by Ashley and Jamie.
• Patrick Saunders (deceased) - 35 years old, Ashley's step-uncle. Molested Ashley as a child; after Zero Hour he became the leader of a pack of cannibals.
• Corporal Elena Reyes - communications officer at the Appalachian Bunker; makes contact with Jamie and Ashley on Day 290.
13.title: Characters

14.content:
Appalachian Bunker (aka Appalachia) - one of dozens of survival bunkers built by the government. Was the intended destination of Ashley and Jamie.

The Bunker - a privately built bunker located underneath the Saunders' house. Becomes the home of Jamie, Ashley and Caleb.
